entry.title: Re: U.S Tax Reporter Year End 2025
entry.content:
@DennyH you can still use /484 in the customizing for box 14;

Refer to SAP note 544849:

      . How are box 14 items configured?

 

Answer: Attach wage types to be reported for box 14 items to the appropriate tax form groups W24A -W24J as appropriate via the IMG step: Payroll USA -> Tax Reporter -> Tax Form Groups -> Define Tax Form groups containing non-tax tax form groups.

You have more details on the note.

Kind regards,
Graziela

entry.title: Unable to find "Maintain Communication Users" or "SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR" in Cloud Shared Trial
entry.content:
Hi Everyone,

I am currently working through a development scenario in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Shared Trial (US10). I have created a custom Communication Scenario in Eclipse (ADT) and I am now trying to set up the inbound communication.

According to the documentation, I need to use the Maintain Communication Users app to create a technical user (ZXE3_FITFOR). However, I am facing the following issues:

  • App Missing: The "Maintain Communication Users" app does not appear in my Fiori Launchpad or in the App Finder.

  • Role Missing: I cannot find the SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR role template to assign the necessary permissions to my user.

  • Restricted Access: I attempted to check the Technical Monitoring Cockpit, but it only provides read-only metrics and no user creation capabilities.

I understand that the Shared Trial is a restricted environment. Is it possible to activate the SAP_CORE_BC_COM (Communication Management) catalog in this specific trial, or is this administrative functionality completely disabled for shared users?

If this is a limitation of the Shared Trial, would moving to a BTP ABAP Environment Trial be the correct path to gain the administrator rights needed for Communication Management?

Any guidance would be greatly appreciated!

entry.title: How to Merge the two different payment methods into one XML file
entry.content:
Hello Team

 

I have situation from customer, i have 4 payment methods 

1. X and Y (cross boarder wire /domestic wire) 

2 A and C (Cross boarder ACH /Domestic Ach) 

 

Customer wants to merge both wire payments into 1 BCM batch for payment method X and Y (both cross border and domestic wires) and same as ACH, can you help me how to config this,  i have tried grouping rules - Country and both payments (X and Y ) but when i perform FBPM1 its creating two different batches for X and Y , Even i removed country its creating two different batches for X and Y , if keep only country its creating one batch for X and Y but it will take other payments also into same batch 

 

hoping that someone will assist me

entry.title: SAP Cloud ALM for Operations Content Now Available in the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Road Map
entry.content:
SAP has added new SAP Cloud ALM for Operations tasks to the SAP Cloud ALM Public Cloud road map. These tasks seamlessly integrate SAP Cloud ALM for Operations functionality into the overall road map, helping customers easily navigate monitoring setup as part of their implementation journey.

The new tasks provide guided setup for the available monitoring capabilities for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. They can be found under the Production Operations Monitoring in SAP Cloud ALM deliverable in the Realize phase and include:

  • Business Process Monitoring ‚Äì Monitor end-to-end business processes using predefined and custom KPIs to detect issues early.
  • Integration & Exception Monitoring ‚Äì Gain visibility into integrations with consistent alert handling.
  • User Monitoring ‚Äì Analyze real user experience and proactively monitor availability using synthetic scenarios.
  • Job & Automation Monitoring ‚Äì Centrally monitor scheduled jobs and automation across SAP solutions.
  • Health Monitoring ‚Äì Assess technical and operational system health using metrics from SAP cloud services.

These tasks represent the first set of SAP Cloud ALM for Operations content, with additional tasks planned for Q1 2026. Please check back for future updates on the available monitoring capabilities as new content is released.

entry.title: 04 SAP SuccessFactors HCM Implementation - Current HCM System Assessment and Outcomes
entry.content:
This blog outlines the key areas to focus on when analyzing the current state of your HCM system. A comprehensive current-state analysis is the foundation of a successful SAP SuccessFactors implementation, ensuring the transition is not merely a ‚Äúlift and shift‚Äù of legacy challenges into a new environment, but a thoughtful, strategic transformation that delivers long-term value.

In my previous post, I covered the objectives of Phase 0; this article continues the series by focusing on assessing the current HCM system.

https://community.sap.com/t5/human-capital-management-blog-posts-by-sap/01-sap-successfactors-hcm-implementation-phase-0-objectives/ba-p/14287328

We typically cover the following areas in the assessment, which vary by customer based on complexity and global presence.

  • Current HCM Modules and Systems
  • Future state role of the current HCM System
  • Customizations  and Pain Points
  • Integrations Assessment
  • Data Assessment

1. Current HCM System Modules in the landscape:

 Having info on which systems are currently "live" and which specific modules are active within each country. This identifies where local "point solutions" (like a local payroll provider) might be operating outside of your global Core HR system. This information is critical for SI to develop the right deployment strategy.

 Workforce Volume & Classification:

 Capture employee volume statistics for all categories and countries. This will help with the Data migration scope, effort, localization requirements, etc.

  • Active Employees: Full-time or part-time workers currently on payroll and working.
  • Inactive Employees: Individuals still "on the books" but not working (e.g., long-term disability, sabbatical, or maternity leave where the contract is still active).
  • Terminated Employees:
  • Pensioners: Former employees receiving retirement benefits directly through your HCM/Payroll system.
  • Contingents: Non-employee labor (1099s, agency workers, or independent contractors) who may need system access but aren't on your standard payroll.
  • Countries in scope: List down all countries in scope with employee volumes.

 

Country

Active Employees

Inactive (LOA/LTD)

Pensioners / Retirees

Contingent (Contractors)

Terminated Records

Total Global

22200

348

NA

7600

45000

 2. Future State Role of Current HCM:

Transitioning to SAP SuccessFactors is rarely a "flip of the switch" where the old system vanishes instantly. The role of your current HCM System (SAP S/4HANA HCM, PeopleSoft, SAP ERP HCM, Workday, Lawson, UKG..etc ) depends entirely on your specific future needs. Based on my experience, here is how your current HCM system typically functions once SAP SuccessFactors HCM becomes SOS for the Employee record.

  • Co-existence : 

This is the most common scenario for large enterprises. In a  Core Hybrid deployment, the systems coexist. SAP SuccessFactors HCM might act as the "System of Record" for Core HR, and talent management, while the  ERP continues to handle support payroll, Benefits, time ..etc .

  • Decommissioning: 

You will only fully decommission the current HCM system. This happens once all modules‚Äîincluding Payroll, Time Tracking, and Benefits‚Äîhave been successfully migrated to SAP SuccessFactors HCM. Even then, decommissioning usually takes 1‚Äì3 years to ensure all compliance and tax cycles are completed.

  • Read-Only System: 

During the first 12‚Äì24 months post-implementation, the legacy system often becomes "Read-Only." This allows HR and Audit teams to verify data integrity or look up historical records that weren't migrated to the cloud. You would typically disable "Write" access to prevent data discrepancies between the two systems.

  • Data Archival System: 

Not all historical data is migrated to SuccessFactors HCM . The legacy system‚Äîor a decommissioned version of its database‚Äîserves as the Historical Archive for:

  • Legal compliance (e.g., holding records for 7+ years).
  • Pension and retirement audits.
  • Detailed historical payroll results.

3. Business Process Customizations and Pain Points:

Moving from a current HCM system to SAP SuccessFactors requires a clear-eyed look at your current "technical debt." The goal is to move away from customizations toward Standard Best Practices to enable easier upgrades and reduce maintenance. Here is a structured framework to help you inventory and analyze your current state.

3.1 HCM Customization Inventory:

Document all customizations in the current system and map each to its corresponding SAP SuccessFactors configuration. The System Integrator (SI) SMEs can provide detailed insights and recommendations on how these customizations can be redesigned , implemented in the SuccessFactors HCM

3.2 Gap Analysis: Legacy vs. SuccessFactors:

The "Gap" indicates whether the requirement is truly unique or simply a limitation of your old system. I have seen building a custom solution in the current state as the only way to support specific requirements due to the system's technological limitations.

  • Standard Configuration: Can this be done using SuccessFactors‚Äô "MDF" (Metadata Framework) or Business Rules without custom code?
  • Process Alignment: Does SuccessFactors offer a "Best Practice" way to do this that is actually better than the custom way?
  • Retirement: Is this customization for a process that no longer exists or is no longer valuable?

3.3 Reporting & Data Accessibility

If you can‚Äôt get data out, the system is just a "black box."

  • Shadow Systems: Are departments keeping their own Excel trackers because the HCM reports are "unusable"?
  • Data Silos: Does your custom script prevent data from flowing into your payroll or ERP system?
  • The "Report Request" Queue: If it takes days for an analyst to build a custom SQL query for a simple headcount report, the current state is failing the business.

4. Integrations Assessment: 

Understanding the current state of the HCM integration landscape is critical and focus on the following items. 

  1. Integrations Inventory: List down the current state integrations list with source and target system details
  2. Technical Integration Landscape: Get the current state of the Integration landscape diagram; if not available, create one. This will provide a high-level view that makes the systems involved easy to understand.
  3. Integration Patterns: Get info on how current integrations are built and what type of integration patterns are used. This will help
  4. Integration tools: Understand what integration tools are used in the current landscape ( ABAP Programs, SAP PI/PO, Boomi, MuleSoft, Manual files extract, etc)
  5. Pain Points: Documenting current state integration pain points will help to address in the future state, like data not available in near time, no better visibility of data and integration points, etc. 

Integrations are one of the high-effort items in SAP SuccessFactors HCM implementation projects. Having all the above information will help define the integration deployment strategy, effort, and disposition approach.

PS: Never underestimate the integration effort. 

 5. Data Migration Assessment: 

Understanding where data resides in the current state is critical to a successful implementation. Typically, Foundation, Organizational, and Employee data are migrated to SAP SuccessFactors HCM ‚Äì Employee Central. However, based on business requirements, data from additional SuccessFactors modules‚Äîsuch as performance ratings, open job requisitions, and candidate profiles‚Äîmay also be included in the migration scope.

  • Where data currently sits
  • How clean is the data
  • Categories of data
  • Employee volume- country-wise
  • Country-specific requirements

Current state HCM Assessment Outcomes :

A thorough analysis of the current HCM system is essential from both the customer and Implementation Partner perspectives to accurately scope and plan the implementation. Once detailed information is gathered, it enables the team to:

  1. Define the project scope and overall complexity
  2. Establish realistic and achievable project timelines
  3. Select and align the appropriate deployment strategy
  4. Identify opportunities to redesign and optimize business processes
  5. Highlight key transformation areas to drive business value
  6. Assess and address existing technical debt

entry.title: Re: How replenishment lead time is getting calculated
entry.content:
Replenishment Lead Time (RLT) in SAP is the total time needed to make a material available again after stock runs out, used mainly in MRP for planning and availability checks.

It varies by procurement type set in the Material Master (MRP 2 view, field BESKZ). For beginners, understanding RLT helps grasp how SAP calculates when orders become feasible.
‚Äã
RLT‚úîÔ∏è

RLT represents the full duration‚Äîfrom order creation to goods availability‚Äîfor procuring or producing a material. SAP uses it during ATP checks and MRP runs to determine if demands can be met within this timeframe.

If the requested date falls outside RLT, the system proposes the earliest possible date.
‚Äã
External Procurement (BESKZ = F)‚úîÔ∏è

For materials bought from vendors, RLT sums: Purchasing dept. processing time (from plant customization OPPQ) + Planned delivery time (material master, field PLIFZ, in calendar days) + GR processing time (material master, field WEBAZ, in workdays).

The system adjusts for factory calendar working days, skipping holidays. Example: If processing is 2 days, delivery 10 days, and GR 1 day, RLT ends after these combined periods from order date.
‚Äã
Internal Production (BESKZ = E)‚úîÔ∏è

For in-house made materials, RLT is either the Total Replenishment Lead Time (field WZEIT, workdays) if maintained, overriding others, or In-house production time (field DZEIT) + GR processing time (WEBAZ).

It considers the BOM explosion down all levels for total production time. If WZEIT is set (e.g., 15 days), the system uses that directly.
‚Äã
Both Procurement Types (BESKZ = X)‚úîÔ∏è

SAP calculates RLT twice‚Äîonce for external (F) and once for internal (E)‚Äîthen takes the shorter duration. This allows flexibility based on quotas or sourcing decisions in MRP. The system selects the minimum to optimize planning.

entry.title: Archiving of Onboarding Tasks is not working
entry.content:
Hello again, community! I‚Äôm back asking for your help.

I configured a business rule to archive ONB tasks and also created a batch job to archive those processes following the implementation guide . The client didn‚Äôt have this set up before, and they had more than 7,000 completed, due, and cancelled processes showing on the ONB dashboard.

After implementing the configuration, I tested it several times by manually submitting the job from Provisioning. I noticed that the job was archiving 100 processes per run, so I opened a support ticket to request an increase in capacity. With my approval, support ran a script and increased the limit to 1,000.

After that, I tested it again, but this time it didn‚Äôt archive anything.

So after this brief context, my question is, What could've caused the batch job to stop archiving the processes?. 

I double checked the configuration, here's a quick peak 

Business rule is in place 

Batch job is properly configured with completed status every time is executed

Job owner has Cancel ONB Permission

Event reason used in the ONB2_ProcessClosurePeriodConfig rule, has the employee status maintained

I had never requested an increase to the job capacity before, so I‚Äôm not sure whether that change is related to the fact that the configuration was archiving processes correctly before.

I asked SAP to revert the capacity back to its original value, and after they confirmed it was done, the behavior is still the same.

I found KBA 3151616 which mentions that the issue could be caused by corrupted data, and another KBA (3435316) that refers to pending workflows, so I went ahead and processed all the pending ones and ask to the SAP support agent to check for corrupted data. 

Despite all of this, I‚Äôm still unable to archive the ONB processes.

Has anyone experienced the same issue?

I truly appreciate your comments.

entry.content:

I ran the process manually and checked the audit logs and I see there's at least a few fields (responsibles, execution stage, status, syncStatus)  that need to be updated but can i just brute force it this way? (light blue is assigning on the board, dark blue is releasing the activity) 

I checked the admin portal to see if any business rules were executed when i released the call but didn't see anything.

entry.title: Re: The Value of SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC) in The Context of Business Steering
entry.content:
@thomaselit 

Simple answer to this , is SAP Data is very very important for organizations, however without the  combining this with the unstructured data organizations have in their data lakes and other large Modern Day Cloud Platforms its virtually useless. Hence the BDC fits in this , It took me approx 2 -3weeks to load approx 1.2 Billion Rows of SAP Data into a Databricks Platform for them to combine sales data with their unstructured data for an organization imagine this with zero copy cloning , a matter of seconds . This is the value . Semantic is the cherry on the top as with Snowflake and SAP Databricks I can create the same Agents that would often take me months to do . 

This is the true value of SAP BDC where I can leverage my SAP data  with non SAP Data to solve real world business scenarios . 

Cheers

Afshin

entry.title: Re: How to connect SAP MBC(Multi Banking connectivity) to...
entry.content:
Dear customer

Thank you for reaching out. I understand your concern regarding the inability to locate the relevant documents. After reviewing the situation, I would like to clarify that the solution you are looking for is currently not supported. You can find more details on this topic here: https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-alm/setup-administration/supported-solutions.

Additionally, there are no specific use cases available for this solution at the moment. For further reference, you may visit the following link: https://support.sap.com/en/alm/sap-cloud-alm/operations/expert-portal/setup-managed-services.html?anchorId=section0.

Best Regards,  
Sylas  
SAP Support

entry.title: Re: asset and equipment integration
entry.content:
Hi,

The asset number field does not exist in the equipment master in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, preventing the standard linking functionality . This limitation affects organizations that need to:

  • Track equipment maintenance costs against fixed assets
  • Maintain synchronized master data between PM and FI modules
  • Generate comprehensive asset reports combining operational and financial data

Please refer to the answers in Solved: Is it possible to integrate/link equipment with as... - SAP Community

Votes can be given to the CIP Equipment and Asset integration in cloud.

Also you can check the answers in Business Scenarios for Maintenance Notifications - SAP Community

Please be aware that scope item Integration with Asset Central Foundation (3YE) is in deprecation. I would not recommend you to use it. and check if the successor is in the roadmap.

 

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudo. This motivates me to serve you better.
Br.Bob

entry.title: Re: How to Use Date Management to Configure Service Contract Dates
entry.content:
Hi @Ryutaro_Koizumi,

Thanks for the comment. Sorry for replying you late. 

RoundTimeExp rounds a time to the beginning or ending of a time unit. Therefore, MONTH means a monthly rounding. When combined with the attribute "position" ("B" or "E"), the logic behaves as a monthly rounding starts ("B") or ends ("E") at the specified time.

For example, the XML code below defines a montly rounding starts with the contract start date:

<RoundTimeExp timeunit="MONTH" position="B">
   <!-- Time Expression -->
   <VarTimeExp name="CONTSTART" position="B"/>
</RoundTimeExp>

 I hope this help. Please kindly verify it with your scenarios. 

For more information, please check this blog: How to Create XML Date Rules for Service Contracts

Best Regards,

Wei

entry.title: Seeking Advice on Tools & Methodology for Legacy RFC User Permissions Cleanup
entry.content:
Hello SAP Security & Basis Experts,

We are embarking on a critical security remediation project to address over-privileged RFC users across our SAP landscape with 600+ systems. Many of these users and connections are years old, lack clear ownership, and serve various backend tasks.

Our goal is to understand what business operations each RFC user/interface actually performs and then redesign brand new ones following the principle of least privilege without disrupting genuine business processes.

There are several key challenges we meet:

1) Many RFC users were created long ago with no clear current responsible person.

2) Activities are often triggered by background jobs, making them less visible.

3) We must not miss crucial but infrequent operations (e.g., year-end financial closing), which short-term monitoring would fail to capture.

We are seeking practical advice on the following specifically:

1) Tool Recommendation: beyond native SM19/SM20 and STUSOBTRACE, what commercial or open-source tools have you successfully used for cross-system RFC user discovery, permission analysis, and activity monitoring? What are their pros/cons for this use case?

2) Methodology for business need collection: How do you practically identify the business purpose behind legacy technical RFC accounts? Are there effective techniques for correlating job schedules (SM37), interface configurations (BD64/WE20), and log data to reverse-engineer their function?

3) Capturing low-frequency activities: What is the best practice to ensure yearly/quarterly critical processes are identified? Are there technical methods to trace such execution history?

We greatly appreciate any insights, war stories, or links to useful resources you can share. Thank you for helping us!

entry.title: Custom Retry Wrapper for SAP Cloud SDK HTTP Calls
entry.content:
Custom Retry Wrapper for SAP Cloud SDK HTTP Calls

 

A Technical Justification & Deep Dive

Executive Summary

Most SAP Cloud SDK integrations rely on outbound HTTP calls to external systems. While the SDK provides built-in resilience features such as retries and circuit breakers, real-world integration scenarios often require finer control that goes beyond the default middleware.

To address these requirements, a custom utility function ‚Äî executeHttpRequestWithRetry() ‚Äî was implemented using executeHttpRequest combined with async-retry.

What This Wrapper Delivers

  • Precise control over retry behaviour

  • Per-attempt logging with full visibility

  • Business-aware retry logic (not just technical retries)

  • Clear separation of retryable vs. non-retryable responses

  • Fully consistent retry logic across all services

This document explains why this approach was required, how it aligns with SAP Cloud SDK resilience principles, and what benefits it provides.

1. Introduction

SAP Cloud SDK supports resilience patterns such as retries, timeouts, and circuit breakers. However:

These features require explicit configuration and do not cover every business scenario by default.

In complex integrations, inconsistent API behaviour and intermittent failures are common. To ensure robustness and predictable behaviour across projects, a custom retry layer was introduced.

2. Implementation Overview

2.1 Dependency

npm install async-retry

2.2 Retry Wrapper Implementation

// executeHttpRequestWithRetry.ts
import { executeHttpRequest } from '@sap-cloud-sdk/http-client';
import retry from 'async-retry';

export async function executeHttpRequestWithRetry(
  destination: any,
  requestConfig: any,
  options?: any
) {
  return retry(
    async (bail, attempt) => {
      try {
        console.log(`Attempt ${attempt} with URL: ${requestConfig?.url}`);
        return await executeHttpRequest(destination, requestConfig, options);
      } catch (error: any) {
        // Bail out if API returns misleading 2xx status with business error
        if (error?.response?.status?.toString().startsWith('2')) {
          bail(error);
        }

        console.log(`Error in attempt ${attempt}: ${error.message}`);
        throw error;
      }
    },
    {
      retries: 3
    }
  );
}

2.3 Service Usage Example

// service.ts
public async methodName(userId: string) {
  const response = await executeHttpRequestWithRetry(
    { destinationName: SF_DESTINATION_NAME },
    { method: HTTP_METHODS.GET, url: this.buildUrl(userId) },
    { fetchCsrfToken: false }
  );

  return response?.data?.d?.results?.[0] ?? null;
}

3. Why a Custom Wrapper Was Needed

(Based on SAP Cloud SDK Resilience Guidelines)

3.1 Full Control Over Retry Behaviour

SAP Cloud SDK retry middleware follows generic retry patterns. In practice, we needed:

  • A custom retry count

  • Visibility into each retry attempt

  • Explicit control over retryable vs. non-retryable errors

With the custom wrapper, logs such as:

Attempt X with URL: ...

provide full traceability, which is not available by default in the SDK.

3.2 Intelligent, Business-Aware Error Handling

Some APIs return 2xx HTTP status codes even when business logic fails (e.g., partial upserts, invalid payloads).

if (error.response.status starts with 2) bail(error);

This ensures:

  • Misleading 2xx business failures ‚Üí No retry

  • Genuine technical failures (5xx, network issues) ‚Üí Retry automatically

SAP Cloud SDK resilience middleware does not provide this level of business-aware filtering.

3.3 Consistent Retry Logic Across Microservices

SDK resilience features must be configured per client or via global providers, which can be missed or misconfigured.

The wrapper guarantees:

  • Identical retry behaviour

  • Uniform error handling

  • Standardised logging

  • Consistent retry count

across the entire codebase, regardless of which team or developer implements a module.

3.4 Simplified Developer Experience

Instead of configuring resilience for every outbound request, developers simply call:

executeHttpRequestWithRetry(...)

This approach:

  • Reduces configuration mistakes

  • Improves maintainability

  • Ensures predictable behaviour

  • Hides resilience complexity from application developers

3.5 Improved Observability

The wrapper explicitly logs:

  • Each retry attempt

  • Target URL

  • Error messages per attempt

SDK default logging often abstracts retry internals unless advanced logging is enabled.

3.6 Future-Proof Design

Using async-retry enables easy future enhancements:

  • Exponential backoff

  • Custom retry delays

  • Conditional retries (e.g., HTTP 429 throttling)

  • Telemetry and monitoring hooks

These enhancements are significantly easier to implement with a custom retry abstraction.

4. Comparison: Custom Wrapper vs. SAP Cloud SDK Defaults

Aspect SAP Cloud SDK (Generic) Custom Wrapper (async-retry)

Retry Status HandlingGeneric, limited customizationExplicit control over 5xx, 429, network errors; fail-fast on 4xx
ObservabilityRetry logic mostly hiddenPer-attempt logging with full transparency
IdempotencyLimited method-level controlEnforced idempotency, with override options
Backoff & JitterFixed defaultsFully configurable (min/max timeout, factor, randomization)

5. Retry Flow (Conceptual)

Request ‚Üí Attempt 1 ‚Üí Success ‚Üí Return

‚§∑ Failure ‚Üí Retry Decision ‚Üí Attempt 2 ‚Üí ... ‚Üí Max Retries ‚Üí Fail or Bail

6. Benefits Summary

Benefit Description

Per-attempt loggingComplete visibility into retry behaviour
Business-aware retriesPrevents retries on misleading 2xx responses
Consistent behaviourUniform logic across services
Simple developer usageOne function call, no configuration
FlexibilityEasy extension for throttling and backoff
Easier debuggingClear insights into API instability

7. Conclusion

While SAP Cloud SDK provides a strong resilience foundation, real-world enterprise integrations demand deeper control and transparency.

The custom executeHttpRequestWithRetry wrapper successfully extends SDK capabilities by delivering:

  • Predictable and consistent retry logic

  • Business-aware error handling

  • High observability

  • Simplified developer experience

  • Flexibility for future enhancements

This approach ensures reliable, maintainable, and production-grade integrations across all SAP Cloud SDK-based services.

entry.title: Re: Custom verification logic for RF transaction in Public Cloud WM
entry.content:
Hello

I assume you were asking RF logic transaction "05 Internal Processes -> 02 Adhoc WT Creation -> 01 Replenishment for Fixed Bin". Cloud WM didn't provide replenishment for inbound on RF devices. If it's "Replenishment for Fixed Bin" you were asking, it doesn't provide supplier on screen but it provides product for input/scan. No standard functionality to support your requirement. 

Maybe you may try to enhance the transaction by "PERSONAS" . By PERSONAS , it's allowed to customize local logic via JAVA script. Search and find valid API for supplier and then call this suitable API in your enhanced script program (Detail please refer to the SAP provided guide book for personas).  For example you input a barcode string including supplier product quantity in the input box of product on RF screen , the barcode string could be handled and checked first in your enhanced PERSONAS script. Script re-set the input box value by valid product number finally. The correct product number will be transport to SAP standard program. 

Regards,

ZZ

entry.title: Re: Streamline Your SAP Cloud ERP Private Upgrades with the New Release Upgrade Management Applicati
entry.content:
Why is Release Upgrade Manager not part of SAP Cloud ALM?

Planning, tasks, timelines, and responsibilities are already there. Testing, monitoring, readiness checks, and quality gates are also part of everyday life in Cloud ALM.

An upgrade is not an isolated technical event, but a lifecycle issue ‚Äì involving preparation, follow-up work, and operational impacts. That's exactly what Cloud ALM is designed for. An integrated approach would not only reduce the number of tools, but also create true consistency.

Are there any plans in this regard?

PS: Perhaps it is generally unfortunate to use abbreviations that stand for completely different topics in the same context area (Lifecycle Management) ‚Äì especially in an environment where monitoring, upgrades, and ALM are closely intertwined anyway:

RUM = Release Upgrade Management
RUM = Real User Monitoring

entry.title: Re: Archiving of Onboarding Tasks is not working
entry.content:
@LauraUreno Please find below possible causes:I verified your configurations provided and looks good.

1.Does compliance step exist for candidate ? if yes and it is open - then archive will not function properly for candidates whose compliance process is still open.

Solution: Make ensure compliance process is completed.

2.Offboarding Disablement :Offboarding was enabled in the system at one point and Later it was disabled

In this period some offboarding processes were created and now job is failing as offboarding is not enabled and it is trying to archive the offboarding processes

Solution :Make ensure to close open offboarding process OR alternative enable offboarding again in provisioning temporarily so job can archive the processes

if above suggestions does not help and based on your statement post script run ,whole functionality is not working as expected:I would suggest you to open a support ticket and check backend logs why your instance archive job is not functioning properly .

Thanks,

Gopi

entry.title: Re: POST Request Working in Postman but Failing in CPI Wi...
entry.content:
Thanks a lot to @Ryan-Crosby  for pointing out the difference in CSRF token handling. That insight made me dig deeper into how CPI processes response headers.

Here‚Äôs what worked for me:

  • The key was to read the CSRF token and cookies from CamelHttpResponseHeaders after the GET call instead of relying on normal headers.
  • I stored them as Exchange Properties and reused them for the POST request.
  • Also enabled HTTP Session Reuse = On Exchange in the iFlow runtime configuration to maintain the same session.
  • Finally, set the POST headers:
    • X-CSRF-Token = ${property.csrfToken}
    • Cookie = built from Set-Cookie values.

After applying this, the POST request returned 201 Created successfully.

Thanks again for the guidance‚Äîit helped me find the right approach!

entry.title: Re: Report on the characteristics entered in the batches.
entry.content: Hi Angel, There is no list report for characristics value of class (for batch) in Public cloud ERP. You may need to create a custom query by using below CDS views. 1. CDS for Characteristic Characteristic Header: I_ClfnCharacteristicForKeyDate Characteristic Description: I_ClfnCharcDescForKeyDate Characteristic Value: I_ClfnCharcValueForKeyDate Characteristic Value Description: I_ClfnCharcValueDescForKeyDate 2. CDS for Class Class Header: I_ClfnClassForKeyDate Class Description: I_ClfnClassDescForKeyDate Class Keyword: I_ClfnClassKeywordForKeyDate Class Characteristic: I_ClfnClassCharcForKeyDate 3. Object Classification Characteristic Valuation: I_ClfnObjectCharcValForKeyDate Class Assignment: I_ClfnObjectClassForKeyDate

entry.title: Inquiry about how to use the EXECUTE_UPDATE method of the CL_SQL_PREPARED_STATEMENT class
entry.content:
We used the CL_SQL_CONNECTION, CL_SQL_PREPARED_STATEMENT, and CL_SQL_STATEMENT classes in an ABAP program for data DELETE & INSERT processing to a specific Oracle DB. (ADBC)

 

However, we discovered that, perhaps because mass data was transmitted, the requested data deletion/insertion does not work. ( Partially, deleted / input was processed. )

 

First, using‚ÄØCL_SQL_CONNECTION->PREPARE_STATEMENT()‚ÄØwe defined the SQL.
(Ex)‚ÄØDELETE‚ÄØFROM‚ÄØ...‚ÄØWHERE‚ÄØA‚ÄØ=‚ÄØ?‚ÄØand‚ÄØB‚ÄØ=‚ÄØ?‚ÄØ.... )

Then, using‚ÄØCL_SQL_PREPARED_STATEMENT->SET_PARAM_TABLE(),‚ÄØwe set the data.

Finally, we called‚ÄØCL_SQL_PREPARED_STATEMENT->EXECUTE_UPDATE().

 

However, we discovered that the intended number of DELETE/INSERT operations were not being processed.

 

When I reduced the number of transmissions, I confirmed that it operates normally.

How can we determine an appropriate size(SET_PARAM_TABLE),

and could you provide any guide documents or sample programs?

entry.title: Onboarding not initiating for International transfer
entry.content:
Hi All,

We are facing an issue in which Onboarding is not initiating for Employee's international transfer. The user is transferring from Brazil to NLD. In BPE, it is giving the following error:

jobInfo : The country of the work schedule BRA_WS13 does not match the country/region for the selected company. Please choose a global work schedule or one whose country/region matches the country/region for the selected company., There is already a hire record for user. You cannot create another hire record if one already exists., You cannot create a job information record for user  before the effective start date in the hire record., It is not permitted due to your system configuration to process this transfer. To perform the transfer, please terminate this record and then rehire with new employment, HIRINTL for Object eventReason is not a consistent value with the associated Object Country/Region with value NLD

Note: We have replicated the exact scenario in our Dev Instance for same user, and we were able to successfully initiate the international transfer without any issues. (Also, we have not mapped work schedule in recruit to hire data mapping in both prod and UAT)

Please let me know if anyone faced this issue earlier.

SAP SuccessFactors Onboarding

entry.title: Re: S-User extend activation
entry.content:
Hello customer,

In order to extend your S-user validity, I would like to draw your attention that the Expiry Date (expiration date) of regular S-user IDs can only be managed by Super, Cloud, and User Administrators in the User Management application.

To check your company's super user, cloud admins or user admins kindly visit My Important Contacts page.

Then kindly contact your super user, cloud admins or user admins to extend your user validity as per the detailed steps introduced in KBA https://me.sap.com/notes/2930885.

You cannot edit or extend the validity date of your S-user by yourself.

Hope the above information helps.

Thanks and regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: URL routing for CAP apps across BTP subaccounts without workzone
entry.content:
We have a three-tier SAP BTP landscape (BTP_DEV, BTP_QAS, BTP_PROD) with a few CAP-based applications. In parallel, we operate an embedded Fiori Launchpad on our OnPrem system that is also structured in three environments (DEV, QAS, PROD).

Current Situation:

  • CAP apps in the Fiori Launchpad are linked via URL tiles
  • Unfortunately each app in every BTP subaccount has its own unique URL (no subdomain-based routing pattern like dev.apps.btp.com/app1, qas.apps.btp.com/app1
  • All CAP apps have the same name across subaccounts like app1, app2 etc

Requirement: We need a solution to ensure that:

  • The Fiori DEV Launchpad points to CAP Apps in BTP_DEV
  • The Fiori QAS Launchpad points to CAP Apps in BTP_QAS
  • The Fiori PROD Launchpad points to CAP Apps in BTP_PROD

Current Challenge: Since each BTP subaccount generates unique URLs for the same app, we cannot simply use static URLs in the tiles or use a system alias for each enviroonment. We need a dynamic routing mechanism.

What is the recommended approach, if workzone is unfortunately no possibility?
Is there a BTP side url mapping? Would a custom backend service with a customizing table with the CAP app urls be a better approach? Thank you in advance!

entry.title: Positioning SAP Business Data Cloud with SAP Snowflake
entry.content:
Your customers want AI-ready SAP data.  They don‚Äôt want more pipelines, copies, or complexity.

Join our webinar, ‚ÄúPositioning SAP Business Data Cloud with SAP Snowflake,‚Äù to see how SAP Snowflake and SAP BDC connect for SAP Snowflake unlock zero-copy, bidirectional data sharing with Snowflake‚Äôs AI data cloud.

In one focused session, you‚Äôll learn how to:

  • Position SAP Snowflake and SAP BDC connect in exec-level conversations
  • Explain the architecture and integrations in minutes, not slides
  • Navigate the pricing structure so deals move faster
  • Use partner resources to accelerate your next SAP + Snowflake engagement

You‚Äôll also see a concrete demo of SAP BDC connect for SAP Snowflake in the SAP business data fabric‚Äîso you can picture exactly how this lands in your customer‚Äôs landscape.

If you‚Äôre ready to turn ‚ÄúSAP + AI‚Äù from buzzwords into a clear value story, Register now  https://partneredge.sap.com/en/library/education/psd/2025/dec/e_oe_te_w_PSD_WEB_00012365.html

entry.title: Re: Enhancements‚ÄØto‚ÄØCustom CDS Views‚ÄØCreated‚ÄØBased on‚ÄØC-1 Released‚ÄØI_ProjectBillingElement View
entry.content:
Hi @Paul_Richert 

Thank you for your query.

To find out whether you have created custom CDS views based on the I_ProjectBillingElement view, you need to follow these steps:

  1. Open the I_ProjectBillingElement CDS view in Eclipse/ABAP Development Tools (ADT) and check the Where-Used list.

     


  2. From the Object Type list, select Data Definition.




    A list of CDS views you have created based on the I_ProjectBillingElement CDS view will appear. The names of custom CDS views mostly start with YY1*.

    Hope this helps!
    Thank you!

entry.title: Re: TDS Limit in SAP Based on total invoice amount for fi...
entry.content:
Yes configuration alone won‚Äôt solve cumulative PAN-level validation and below would be my suggested approach

  • Fetch Vendor PAN from LFA1-J_1IPANNO.
  • Get all Vendor Codes linked to that PAN.
  • Read Invoice Amounts:
    • If ECC: Use BSIK (open items) + BSAS (cleared items).
    • If S/4HANA: Use ACDOCA.
  • Aggregate cumulative value for the fiscal year (April‚ÄìMarch).
  • Check threshold:
    • If cumulative < ‚Çπ50,00,000 ‚Üí No TDS.
    • If cumulative ‚â• ‚Çπ50,00,000 ‚Üí Apply TDS via enhancement.
  • Enhancement Spot:
    • Typically in BADI / User Exit during MIRO (invoice posting) or F-43 (vendor invoice).
    • Example: BADI_FDCB_SUBBAS01 or RFWT0010 (Withholding Tax exits).
